data.title: Harbor Mid Cap Value Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
"While technology-related stocks saw the largest gains, other sectors of the market also benefited from the broadening of the market advance." - LSV Asset Management

Market in Review

U.S. equities delivered positive gains in the fourth quarter of 2025, consolidating a strong year. The S&P 500 Index increased 2.7% during the quarter, bringing full-year returns to 17.9%. Performance was shaped by the evolving monetary policy backdrop following the Federal Reserve's ("Fed") initial rate cut in September, with additional cuts in October and December, as investors balanced expectations for a gradual easing cycle against evidence of slowing, but still resilient economic fundamentals. The Fed maintained its data-dependent messaging throughout the quarter, signaling willingness to ease further as inflation continued moderating toward its target while labor market conditions softened at the margin. This approach helped contain interest rate volatility and provided support for equity valuations.

Corporate earnings remained broadly positive despite moderating growth rates. Forward guidance pointed to continued, albeit more measured, profit expansion into 2026. AI and technology-related sectors continued to drive earnings leadership, though contributions broadened to include Health Care, Industrials, and Consumer Discretionary stocks.

Mid-cap stocks lagged both large- and small-cap stocks. The Russell 1000® Index was up 2.4%, and the Russell 2000® returned 2.2%, while the Russell Midcap® Index was up just 0.2%. Value stocks – as measured by the Russell Indexes – outperformed growth stocks.

Nine of the 11 S&P 500 sectors posted positive returns in the fourth quarter. Sector leadership was concentrated in the Health Care and Communication Services sectors, while Real Estate and Utilities lagged.

Portfolio Performance

During the fourth quarter, the Harbor Mid Cap Value Fund (Institutional Class, "Fund") returned 4.07%, outperforming its benchmark, the Russell Midcap® Value Index, which returned 1.42%. Among mid-caps, value stocks outperformed growth stocks, as the Russell Midcap® Growth Index returned -3.7%. The outperformance of value stocks had a positive impact on relative results given our value discipline.

We take limited sector and industry bets and look to add value primarily from bottom-up stock selection. During the fourth quarter, stock selection accounted for most of the value added, however, sector selection was also positive. From a sector perspective, the Fund's underweight to Utilities and Real Estate added value. Stock selection added value in several sectors, particularly Industrials, Consumer Discretionary, and Financials.

Contributors & Detractors

Following strong performance in the third quarter, Information Technology holding Sandisk (SNDK) significantly outperformed again in the fourth quarter. AI-driven demand for storage led to strong earnings and increases in revenue growth and margins. We trimmed our position in Sandisk given the run-up in the stock.

Other top-performing holdings were in the Consumer Discretionary sector – General Motors (GM) and Expedia (EXPE). General Motors performed well after posting strong full-year results driven by record truck sales. The company continues to return capital to investors through stock buybacks and dividend increases. Expedia, which was a recent purchase, also posted strong results and raised the outlook going forward. We added to our exposure to Expedia and continue to hold both stocks in the Fund.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ), in the Health Care sector, was a top performer, advancing nearly 30% driven by strong third quarter performance and positive clinical trial results for one of its cancer drugs. We continue to hold the company in the Fund.

Other top contributors included underweights to momentum-based stocks that are in the benchmark, Robinhood Markets (HOOD) and Coinbase Global (COIN).

While several Fund holdings struggled – including NewMarket (NEU) in the Materials sector, HP (HPQ) in the Information Technology sector, and Harley-Davidson (HOG) and PulteGroup (PHM) in the Consumer Discretionary sector – the most significant detractor was our underweight to Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD), which is in the benchmark and was up nearly 50% on acquisition activity. NewMarket struggled with general weakness in the petroleum additives business, one of the larger portions of its revenue. We continue to hold the stock in the Fund. Harley-Davidson struggled after reporting sharp declines in motorcycle revenue, increased costs, and pricing pressure. We continue to hold Harley-Davidson in the Fund. PulteGroup, in the homebuilding industry, struggled due to slowing orders and margin pressures despite a slight decrease in mortgage rates. We continue to hold PulteGroup in the Fund. HP has not benefited much from the AI frenzy like other technology companies. The company has seen rising costs and projected lower-than-expected earnings for 2026. We did not make any changes to our position in HP and continue to hold the stock in the Fund.

Buys & Sells

We initiated a position in Garrett Motion (GTX), an automotive parts and equipment company in the Consumer Discretionary sector. The company designs, manufactures, and sells turbocharger and electric boosting technologies for commercial vehicles. Garrett ranks high on multiple cash flow and forecast earnings measures on our model. The company typically pays a dividend and has been aggressively buying back stock, which we view positively. Price momentum during the past 12 months has been strong as has operating momentum, placing its momentum scores near the top decile. Overall, the stock ranks in the top 5% in our stock-ranking universe, which led to the fourth quarter purchase.

We also initiated a position in EnerSys (ENS) in the Industrials sector. EnerSys designs, manufactures, and distributes energy systems and batteries to customers worldwide. The stock ranks high on multiple cash flow and forecast earnings measure — our two most important blocks of valuation. The company typically pays a dividend and has been aggressively buying back stock, which we view positively. Price momentum over the past 12 months has been strong. In addition, several indicators of operating momentum are also attractive, with improving operating margins and growth in sales. Overall, the stock ranks in the top 5% in our stock-ranking universe, which led to the fourth quarter purchase.

We sold our position in Electronic Arts (EA) in the Communication Services sector. Electronic Arts did well in 2025, advancing approximately 40% for the year. In late September, the company announced an agreement to be acquired by Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, Silver Lake (SVLKF), and Affinity Partners for $55 billion. The Fund often benefits from takeovers, as the companies we hold tend to be attractively priced, solid businesses that are undervalued, as was the case with Electronic Arts.

We trimmed our position in Amkor Technology (AMKR) in the Information Technology sector. Amkor has done well in recent years, benefiting from the surging demand in AI and as a result has become less attractive from a valuation standpoint. While the stock still generates good cash flow, both earnings and cash flow have not kept up with the increase in stock price. Stock price momentum has been very strong but the decline in fundamentals (valuation) led us to sell the position.

Sector Underweights and Overweights

The Fund's sector exposures are driven by valuations, as we will overweight those sectors where we find the most attractive stocks from a valuation standpoint and underweight those sectors and industries where we have difficulty finding cheap stocks.

The Fund's most significant overweights relative to the value benchmark are to the Consumer Discretionary and Financials sectors. Within the Consumer Discretionary sector, the Fund is overweight homebuilders, automotive parts, automotive retail, and broadline retail. Among Financials, the Fund is overweight consumer finance, commercial & residential mortgage finance, asset management & custody banks, regional banks, and property & casualty insurance. The most significant underweights relative to the value benchmark are to Industrials, Materials, Utilities, and Real Estate.

Outlook

U.S. equity markets finished the year strong; however, mid-cap stocks were only slightly positive in the fourth quarter and up just over 10% for the year compared to nearly 18% for the S&P 500 Index. Markets in 2025 were led by almost anything AI-related, driving up valuations for chipmakers and software firms building AI platforms. While technology-related stocks saw the largest gains, other sectors of the market also benefited from the broadening of the market advance.

Even though AI-related technology stocks may appear priced to perfection, we continue to identify opportunities among mid- and smaller-capitalization value stocks. The Fund has outperformed the value benchmark in four of the past five years, with the only exception being 2024, when the Fund matched the return of the value benchmark. Even with strong relative performance, the Fund remains attractively priced relative to the benchmark. The Fund seeks to hold high-quality, profitable companies that generate cash, pay dividends, and repurchase shares. While large-cap U.S. stocks appear quite expensive, the mid- and small-cap segments of the market continue to trade at attractive multiples, particularly value-oriented stocks. We remain committed to our disciplined value investment approach and are excited about the opportunities available to investors among mid- and small-cap value stocks.

Important Information

Risks

There is no guarantee that the investment objective of the Fund will be achieved. Stock markets are volatile and equity values can decline significantly in response to adverse issuer, political, regulatory, market and economic conditions. The value of securities selected using quantitative analysis can react differently to issuer, political, market, and economic developments than the market as a whole or securities selected using only fundamental analysis. The factors used in quantitative analysis and the weight placed on those factors may not be predictive of a security's value. In addition, any model may contain flaws or the model may not perform as anticipated. Stocks of mid cap companies pose special risks, including possible illiquidity and greater price volatility than stocks of larger, more established companies.

Benchmarks

The Russell Midcap® Value Index is an unmanaged index generally representative of the U.S. market for medium capitalization value stocks. This unmanaged index does not reflect fees and expenses and is not available for direct investment. The Russell Midcap® Value Index and Russell® are trademarks of Frank Russell Company.

Disclosures

All holdings-related data is provided by FactSet. Because FactSet relies on external sources for its data, that data may differ slightly from actual values maintained by Harbor Funds.

Due to the security valuation procedures of the Fund and intra-day trading activity not included in the FactSet calculations, the actual returns may vary. From time to time the cash return in the portfolio may appear distorted based on the way FactSet's attribution calculation methodology addresses delayed settlements.

Best and Worst Performers sections reflect stocks in the portfolio for the quarter with an average weight of 0.25% or greater.

Views expressed herein are drawn from commentary provided to Harbor by the subadvisor and may not be reflective of their current opinions or future actions, are subject to change without prior notice, and should not be considered investment advice.

This information should not be considered as a recommendation to purchase or sell a particular security. The weightings, holdings, industries, sectors, countries, and returns mentioned may change at any time and may not represent current or future investments.

As a result of changing market conditions, expenses and other statistics may change at any time and may differ from those shown.

Sector allocations are determined using the Global Industry Classification Standard (GICS), which is a service of Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) and Standard & Poor's (S&P).

Investors should carefully consider the investment objectives, risks, charges and expenses of a fund before investing. To obtain a summary prospectus or prospectus for this and other information, visit Active ETFs or call 800-422-1050. Read it carefully before investing.

Distributed by Harbor Funds Distributors, Inc.

Attribution Disclosures

Attribution results are calculated by Harbor Capital based on fund holdings data obtained from State Street Bank and Trust Company and return data sourced from MSCI Inc. Where MSCI return data is unavailable, FactSet data is used as a substitute. Benchmark holdings are sourced from the respective index provider. Attribution results are based on end-of-day portfolio positions and calculated gross of any fees and expenses.

Active Currency Contribution is the Currency Contribution of the portfolio minus the Currency Contribution of the benchmark.

Allocation Effect is the portion of portfolio excess return that is attributable to taking different group bets from the benchmark. (If either the portfolio or the benchmark has no position in a given group, allocation effect is the lone effect.) A group's allocation effect equals the average percent capitalization of the portfolio's group minus the average percent cap of the benchmark's group times the total return of the benchmark group minus the total return of the benchmark.

Average Weight is the dollar value (price times the shares held) of the security or group, divided by the total dollar value of the entire portfolio displayed as a percentage. It is calculated as the simple arithmetic average of daily values.

Contribution to Return is the contribution of a security or group to the overall portfolio return. It is calculated as the security weight multiplied by the daily security return linked daily across the reporting period.

Currency Contribution is Total Return in USD subtracting out the Local Returns.

Local Returns are the Total Return of the portfolio or benchmark using the local currency.

Selection Effect is the portion of portfolio excess return attributable to choosing different securities within groups from the benchmark. A group's security selection effect equals the average weight of the benchmark's group times the total return of the portfolio's group minus the total return of the benchmark's group.

Total Effect is the sum of Allocation Effect and Selection Effect. The total effect represents the opportunity cost of what was done in a group relative to the overall portfolio. It is not just the difference between percent contribution in the portfolio and benchmark. At the overall portfolio level, the two numbers are equal. At the group level, they can be different.

Total Return is the price change of a security or group including dividends accrued over the report period (or the in-portfolio return) which includes only the time period that each security was in the portfolio.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Hut 8 Focuses On AI Infrastructure Growth, But Operating Profitability Is Still A Work In Progress
data.description:
I last covered Hut 8 (HUT) in November, and downgraded my rating on the company to a hold, citing their lack of operating profitability as they try to restructure the company into an energy optimization and infrastructure provider out of what was once a fairly straightforward Bitcoin mining venture.

The problems were two-fold, that the increase in share price was commanding a substantial premium to the value of the underlying Bitcoins, and that because the infrastructure business isn’t yet at break-even, that Bitcoin asset is really the only meaningful thing they own right now at a scale which means anything to shareholders.

Now we’re another quarter deep, and we’ve got the final numbers for the year. This is a good opportunity to see where the business itself stands, but also importantly a chance to reexamine the Bitcoin side of things, because the price of Bitcoins in February of 2026 isn’t what it was even a few short months ago.

Growth Is Meaningful, But Bitcoin Losses Are the Story in Q4

After positive quarters in which Hut 8’s profits were more or less entirely a function of their digital assets (which is to say, Bitcoin) appreciating in value, Q4 saw them not just turn to loss, but decidedly so. Once again, the bottom line is driven overwhelmingly by what the price of Bitcoin did, going down in this case.

($2.53)

(source: press release from Q4 earnings)

Top line growth is meaningful year over year here, of course, but once again the Gain on Digital Assets line dwarfs everything else, and by the time we get to net income we’re left with either positive earnings that are exclusively from that gain, as in 2024, or a net loss that is the loss on digital assets compounded with further operating losses from the rest of the business.

One could argue, indeed, that the earnings we were seeing in past quarters are largely illusory, because the gains are entirely on paper in estimations of what digital assets are worth, and since the company never seems willing to divest those assets when they appreciate, they’re just gains until we get a quarter like this past one, where the price drops and suddenly they’re booking a loss.

Which isn’t to say that the Bitcoin holdings are worthless. As Hut 8 moves to redefine itself away from its crypto business they managed to bring in some positive cash flow from the creation of the American Bitcoin stock. But such gains are not something we can expect them to be able to repeat, nor are they something to judge the overall business around.

Cash Flow and the Margins of the Business

Putting aside the Bitcoin question for a minute, we should look at a breakdown of the revenue by different segments of the company. The conference call comment was quite accurate declaring that Compute is the company’s “real growth engine” of the company’s business, and indeed, as it grows the margin of that segment has remained the strongest.

Revenue

(source: press release from Q4 earnings)

From the point of view of revenue, Compute is by far the largest source, and the highest margin of the bunch. The revenue more than doubled year over year, from $31.7 million in 2024, and the margin maintained strength. So long as they are able to continue to grow the Compute segment going forward, it’s clear that’s the right decision to focus on, and the company seems to believe that AI demand for such services is going to allow them to grow that capacity into 2026 and beyond.

On the other hand, Hut 8 stands as an over $6 billion market cap company, and for the entire fiscal year, their overall revenue was only $235 million, with gross costs of around $108 million. That’s a price/sales of 26.07, which is both enormous compared to the sector median of 3.20 and much higher than Hut 8’s own 5-year average of 9.95.

That problem is compounded because once you get through the gross costs and into the operating costs, that revenue is more than entirely burned through. Noteworthy is that operating cash flow in 2025 actually was worse, even though the revenue and gross margin were substantially higher.

FY 2024

FY 2025

Total Revenue

(source: Latest 10-K from SEC)

Herein lies the problem: Hut 8 is growing, but the top line revenue is still paltry for a company their size, and that growth isn’t bringing them closer to operating break-even so far. When trying estimate the underlying value of Hut 8 we have to include not only their tangible assets, which are largely Bitcoins and depreciating equipment, but also what the cash generation potential of the business is actually worth. In this case, the latter is seemingly worth very little at present. That could change, but for now, it’s not a $6 billion business.

Looking at the other cash flow lines, we see Investing Cash Flow is strongly negative, both because of substantial CapEx in both years ($120 million in 2024 and roughly $197 million in 2025) which, again, operations aren’t able to pay for, and because they continue to spend large amounts of money buying more Bitcoins.

The Financing Cash Flow line is where Hut 8 is ultimately paying for all this, and in both cases that included issuing more debt, though also issuing more shares of common stock, which is obviously going to have dilutive consequences for investors.

Underlying Value on the Balance Sheet

Cash and Equivalents

$44.9 million

Total Current Assets

$408 million

Total Current Liabilities

$376 million

Digital Assets

$1.3 billion

Property and Equipment

$643 million

Shareholder Equity

$1.42 billion

(source: Latest 10-K from SEC)

Hut 8 has a modest balance sheet all told, in that they have a not great but sufficient current ratio of 1.09, and a price/book ratio of 4.31, which isn’t hugely higher than the sector median of 3.51.

None of this would be immediately objectionable if Hut 8 was a business with positive operating cash flow. With that not being the case, however, valuation has to be justified almost entirely through digital assets. That raises the question of both risk and potential upside, and we find that despite restructuring itself substantially, that’s still a matter of Bitcoin prices.

We saw in Q4 that if Bitcoin prices depreciate bottom line is going to go down with it, irrespective of how the rest of the company is executing. On the other hand, if Bitcoin prices quickly rebounded and tested new highs, history suggests that investors would reward Hut 8 shareholders on the basis on the substantial assets they’re holding.

Outside of the digital assets, however, there’s not much here, as Hut 8 also has growing debt and equipment that includes a lot of the type of technology that depreciates rapidly over time. Here again, a balance sheet with a lot of such equipment would be easier to justify if Hut 8 was using that equipment to generate cash flow, but so far they simply aren’t.

Hope Springs Eternal Even If Bitcoin Doesn’t

Hut 8 has growth prospects in its business, and conceivably there is a future in which their GPU-as-a-service business model grows to the point that they are able to generate good cash flow with it. The gross margin in their Compute segment reflects that. It’s just right now that segment is far too small for a company of their size, and growth remains a work in progress.

I’m going to reiterate a hold rating on Hut 8, even though I feel that the stock is as it stands somewhat overpriced for what you’re getting, because the growth potential of their business can’t be discounted, and the market seemingly is willing to pay a substantial multiple for exposure to Bitcoin price increases. I honestly think the path of least resistance for Bitcoin bulls would be to buy Bitcoins, but clearly there is a market for miners, and even in the case of Hut 8, former miners.

The Q4 conference call shows that the corporate officers remains highly bullish about the direction they’re taking Hut 8. I don’t think the current share price is particularly enticing, but those who believe in the business model should keep a close eye on how they grow and, importantly, how soon they are able to get to operating break-even, because the future of this company depends heavily on getting there.

data.title: Zscaler's AI-Powered Security: A Compelling Case For Aggressive Growth Investors
data.description:
My November 12, 2025 article recommended buying Zscaler (NASDAQ: ZS). Unfortunately, that recommendation has yet to prove fruitful. Poor investor reaction to the company’s first-quarter fiscal year ("FY") 2026 results, released on November 25, 2025, was largely responsible for the first leg of the company’s poor performance over the last three months.

The second leg of the stock’s decline was due to investors selling off the stock in response to the SaaSpocalypse narrative, which had beaten down the valuations of many software-as-a-service ("SaaS") companies in early February 2026, as some investors became unwilling to accept SaaS companies' higher risk. An author of a recent Seeking Alpha article explained their reasoning for selling Salesforce (CRM) and FactSet (FDS) due to the SaaSpocalypse risk:

Overall, I don’t think that AI [Artificial Intelligence] will bankrupt every SaaS company, but most of them will face a turning point. What has worked in the past might not work in the future, and since the technological innovations are so fast, I decided to sell both companies [Salesforce and FactSet] in early January (lucky timing in hindsight). This doesn’t mean that Salesforce and FactSet can’t generate significant returns; it just means that these two businesses now present a risk/reward ratio that no longer fits my risk tolerance.

Investors are concerned that autonomous AI agents might reduce demand for "seat-based" licensed software from SaaS companies, which reduces recurring revenue per user (or "seat") accessing a digital software tool or platform. In early February, Anthropic released the Claude Cowork AI agent, which may eliminate human jobs and, in theory, harm some SaaS companies' recurring revenue. Zscaler's stock dropped amid concerns that its Annual Recurring Revenue (”ARR”) growth could decelerate.

However, Zscaler already has an AI agent licensing program through AI Guard. The company's website states that AI Guard "is licensed based on a platform subscription fee and the number of tokens purchased for the subscription term in an order." Since some believe AI agents will eventually outnumber human workers, Zscaler potentially has a large pool of non-human AI agents to generate revenue from, replacing revenue lost due to the SaaSpocalypse.

Because Zscaler could make money from Agentic AI, this recent dip might be a good chance to buy the stock.

AI Security as a Significant New Revenue Pillar

Although the market is currently highly concerned that AI might be a deal-breaker for investing in Zscaler, it has actually become a concrete financial contributor, enough that management considers AI Security its third revenue growth pillar, alongside its original pillar of Zero Trust Everywhere and its second pillar of Data Security Everywhere.

Zscaler's AI Security can be broken down into two buckets: Security for AI apps and Agentic Operations. The simplest way to think of it is that Agentic Operations uses AI to automate ITOps (Information Technology operations) and SecOps (Security operations), while Security for AI apps provides security for AI apps and the data flowing into them.

The image above shows several platforms under Agentic operations. Under ITOps, the company names Zscaler Digital Experience™ (ZDX), a service that enables IT teams to detect, troubleshoot, and resolve user and customer experience issues across devices and software, and ZDX CoPilot, an AI-powered virtual assistant for the ZDX platform. Although the company has yet to announce further plans in ITOps, it appears to be leaning toward making all IT operations autonomous. So, investors should look out for further services under the ITOps umbrella.

SecOps combines IT operations and information security to strengthen an organization's cybersecurity posture by providing tools to help the CISO (Chief Information Security Officer) assess risks to the company's assets. Some of these tools include Risk360, a service that shows an organization's top cyber risk exposures and possible financial impacts. Other tools include Business Insights, an analytics tool that shows a business how employees and customers use its SaaS apps and office space, Unified Vulnerability Management (UVM), a cloud-native risk‑based vulnerability management system that shows the CISO which security vulnerabilities actually matter and how to fix them, Identity Threat Detection, which shows the company when attackers are trying to misuse, steal, or abuse a company’s accounts and credentials, and Cyber Asset Attack Surface Management (CAASM), which gives management creates a clean, authoritative inventory of all the company's assets.

Zscaler also includes Red Canary under Agentic Operations. Zscaler closed its $675 million acquisition of Red Canary, a Managed Detection and Response (MDR) provider, on August 1, 2025. MDR is a service that combines advanced security tools with human threat hunters to prevent data breaches. Red Canary has gotten off to an excellent start. Chief Financial Officer ("CFO") Kevin Rubin said at the Barclays 23rd Annual Global Technology Conference:

So as we had mentioned going into the quarter, we expected Red Canary to contribute $83 million of ARR at the close. So that was the amount of underlying business that we picked up. And then we had shared that we expected Red Canary to deliver $95 million throughout fiscal '26, which effectively implies, if you just straight line it, $3 million a quarter. And our commentary was that they actually did a little better than that in Q1. So in addition to the underlying strength we saw in our organic business, we also saw better performance in the Red Canary in the quarter.

The commentary indicates Red Canary’s first-quarter ARR is growing faster than management initially forecast, suggesting Zscaler is already cross-selling Red Canary to its user base and that the consolidation is likely going smoothly.

Security for AI apps lets companies safely leverage tools like ChatGPT, Claude, and other generative AI systems, without users or AI agents leaking data or violating compliance rules, while keeping employees productive. The cybersecurity risks posed by AI aren't only theoretical. Chief Executive Officer ("CEO") Jay Chaudhry said on the first-quarter FY 2026 earnings call: "One of the largest AI companies recently reported that a bad actor hijacked its AI coding assistant to autonomously perform a large-scale cyberattack against multiple organizations."

Security for AI Applications includes AI guard, which acts as a guardrail for AI by monitoring real-time prompts and responses, blocking malicious inputs, and securing sensitive data; AI Asset Discovery, which limits AI asset sprawl by finding every AI system an organization uses; and Secure Access to AI Apps, which provides Zero Trust access controls (allows only the right people and agents use secure AI tools).

Zscaler AI Red Teaming, not to be confused with Red Canary, is a service that uses automated tools to simulate an attack to test whether an organization's AI can be tricked, misled, or abused before a real hacker attack. On November 3, 2025, the company acquired SPLX, a startup that Zscaler wanted for its core Red Teaming product.

CEO Chaudhry said on the first quarter earnings call:

As part of AI life cycle, customers need to regularly test their applications for vulnerabilities. With SPLX, we now deliver AI Red teaming to enable automated and continuous testing of AI apps at scale. Our AI Red teaming solution integrates with customers' CI/CD [Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery] pipelines, making it easy to test for hallucination, bias, behavior drift and more. Several customers, including a Fortune 150 transportation company and a Fortune 100 service provider have already deployed AI Red teaming.

Be careful not to get confused when management discusses AI, as it is easy to mistake whether they are referring to the overall AI Security segment or to the subsegments: Security for AI apps and Agentic Operations. When investors parse through earnings calls for information about its AI initiatives, make sure to clearly understand what management is referring to.

For instance, Chief Executive Officer ("CEO") Jay Chaudhry forecasted that Agentic Operations would reach $400 million in ARR by the end of FY 2026 during the fourth-quarter FY 2025 earnings call. However, CEO Chaudry said on the first quarter FY 2026 earnings call:

I'm particularly pleased with our AI Security pillar, which grew over 80% year-over-year and has already exceeded our FY '26 target of $400 million ARR, 3 quarters earlier than expected. With the strong demand, I expect AI Security ARR to exceed $0.5 billion by the end of this fiscal year.

Note that on the fourth-quarter earnings call, Chaudry discussed the subsegment Agentic Operations alone, whereas on the first-quarter FY 2026 earnings call, he referred to the overall AI segment. If you put the two statements together, management expects $400 million from Agentic Operations and infers $100 million from Security for AI apps for a total of $0.5 billion in ARR by the end of FY 2026.

The AI Security pillar's first-quarter FY 2026 growth of 80% year over year and ARR exceeding FY' 26 targets three quarters earlier than expected indicate Zscaler's AI initiatives are growing like a weed, evidence that the SaaSpocalypse narrative of agentic AI hurting Zscaler may be in error.

Excellent first quarter fiscal year ("FY") 2026 results

Zscaler had a "beat and raise" quarter, beating its own first-quarter guidance and analysts' estimates. Management's initial revenue guidance for FY 2026 was $3.676 billion to $3.698 billion, reflecting year-over-year growth of 21.9% to 22.7%. The company raised its annual revenue guidance for FY 2026 in the first quarter to $3.282 billion to $3.301 billion, reflecting year-over-year growth of 22.8% to 23.5%.

Although the company reported strong non-GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles) earnings per share ("EPS") of $0.96, beating analysts' estimates of between $0.85 and $0.86, management reported a GAAP net loss of $11.6 million. Some investors are becoming increasingly fed up with the gap between non-GAAP and GAAP numbers, likely driven by high stock-based compensation ("SBC"). The company's SBC as a percentage of total revenue was 24.58% at the end of the first quarter, very high compared to other tech companies.

ZScaler also reported non-GAAP gross margins of 79.91%, a 66 basis points ("bps") year over year decline from 80.57%. CFO Rubin gave the following reasoning for the gross margin dip:

I'd like to remind investors that we are introducing new products that are experiencing strong growth and are optimized for faster go-to-market rather than margins. This will continue to influence our gross margins on a quarterly basis. We plan to optimize new products for margins over time as they scale.

Although this is a valid reason, growth investors may lower their valuation of a stock if gross margins decline. Investors also disliked this commentary from the CFO: "With a large market opportunity and customers increasingly adopting the broader platform, we will invest aggressively to position us for long-term growth and profitability." Investors are concerned that "investing aggressively" may slow operating margin expansion, thereby delaying the time to GAAP profitability.

Despite the increased FY 2026 revenue guidance, analysts' FY 2026 revenue estimates of $3.28 billion to $3.30 billion were seen as in line with expectations, and, at Zscaler's valuation on November 25, the market wanted to see expectations blown away to continue awarding it a premium valuation.

As a result, the stock dropped 13% the day after the company released its first-quarter FY 2026 results.

What to look for moving forward

One of the most important numbers to monitor the health of a SaaS company is ARR, as it measures renewal strength, forward revenue visibility, underlying demand, upsell/cross‑sell momentum, and the durability of the business model. Since a difference as small as 5% in growth rates can markedly change compounding over three to five years, investors should watch Zscaler's ARR to see if it can re-accelerate growth above 25%. The market will generally award a premium SaaS multiple (15–20× forward revenue) to a stock with a 25% ARR growth rate, a mid‑tier SaaS forward multiple (10–14×) to a stock with a 20–25% ARR growth rate, and a legacy SaaS multiple (6–9×) to a stock with less than a 20% ARR growth rate. Since Zscaler currently trades at a 7.728 multiple, the market may be pricing in that Zscaler's ARR growth will settle in the lower end of a 20% to 25% range and that it will be unable to reaccelerate ARR above 25%. Some investors may believe the company currently sits at fair value.

However, the market could still re-rate the valuation upwards if Zscaler maintains over 20% ARR growth over multiple years; AI Security sustains over 80% growth, or AI Security ARR exceeds $0.5 billion by the end of fiscal 2026. AI Security beating management's growth targets early (in the second or third quarter) may indicate it is winning the cybersecurity "AI arms race," justifying a premium valuation.

Zscaler's Remaining Performance Obligation (RPO) growth of 35% compared to revenue growth of 26% might be interpreted by some investors as a buy signal. RPO is a future-oriented measure that represents the total value of contracted revenue yet to be recognized. The market interprets RPO growing faster than revenue as the sales pipeline strengthening (revenue visibility improving), the sales team executing larger or longer deals, or potential revenue acceleration. The market may price in a higher revenue multiple if Zscaler can maintain RPO growth in the 30–35% range or higher, revenue growth in the mid‑20s, and ARR growth in the low‑20s or higher.

A word of caution, RPO doesn't perfectly predict future revenue acceleration as the mix of contract duration, billing terms, deal size, and seasonality can sway the number either positively or negatively. So, only use RPO as one piece of the puzzle.

The last area you should closely monitor is the company's rule of 78, an offshoot of 40, a metric invented in 2015 by venture capitalists Brad Feld and Fred Wilson to assess whether a SaaS company's growth is sustainable. The rule states that a SaaS company's revenue growth rate plus its profit margin should be at least 40%. The earliest version of the equation didn't explicitly specify which profit margin to use. However, Brad Feld did post in a blog the following comment:

Profit is harder to define. Are we talking about EBITDA [Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization], Operating Income, Net Income, Free Cash Flow, Cash Flow or something else. I prefer to use EBITDA here as the baseline and then back test with the other percentages.

One reason he stated it that way is that different profit margins can produce different results. For instance, the company uses its first-quarter FY 2026 FCF margin of 52% and its 26% revenue growth to calculate what it calls the Rule of 78, which would be one of the best in the industry. However, if you use the company's non-GAAP operating margin of 22%, the equation would produce a Rule of 48, and if you use its GAAP operating margin of -4.6%, it would equal 21.4, which would be an indication that growth was unsustainable long term, which is a big reason that investors are concerned about the company's GAAP profitability.

The weakness of using the FCF margin is that it is a volatile figure that can swing due to billing cycles, big changes in working capital, and heavy growth investment and Capital Expenditure cycles; it doesn't directly measure a company's profitability. So, caution is warranted when looking at Zscaler's Rule of 78, and you should never compare Zscaler's stated Rule of 78 to a competitor's Rule of 40 measure using different profitability numbers, such as EBITDA margin or Operating margin, because that's like comparing Apples, Oranges, and Pears.

With all of those caveats in mind, as long as Zscaler sustains a FCF margin near 50% while growing revenue above 25%, the market may be more willing to award it a premium valuation.

At the end of the first quarter, its cash and short-term investments were 3.321 billion. The company's convertible senior debt was $1.699 billion, and its operating lease was $0.066 billion, for a total long-term debt of $1.765 billion.

Zscaler's debt-to-equity ratio was 0.925, indicating that the company finances its operations primarily with equity rather than debt. Since a current ratio between 1.0 and 2.0 is the sweet spot for recurring‑revenue SaaS businesses, the company's 1.745 current ratio indicates it is well positioned to cover its near‑term liabilities.

I usually calculate a company's debt-to-EBITDA ratio. However, depending on how an analyst calculates ZScaler's EBITDA, it is close to the borderline between slightly negative and slightly positive. For instance, Seeking Alpha reports ZScaler's TTM EBITDA as -67.7 million. Different third-party websites report its EBITDA as high as $183 million. The company's EBITDA is so close to the profitability threshold that the net-debt-to-EBITDA calculation is not very useful. However, some investors may be concerned about Zscaler's EBITDA being negative or barely profitable. Others believe that the company's prodigious FCF and cash exceeding long-term debt mean it will have little issue repaying the debt.

The major issue is that its long-term debt is convertible, which can dilute existing investors in addition to the substantial SBC.

Valuation

Zscaler's trailing 12-month ("TTM") price-to-sales (P/S) ratio is 8.791, below its three-, five-, and seven-year median. If the company can reaccelerate ARR to 25% or higher, it may return to at least its three-year median. At its three-year median, its price would be $249.50, a 56% rise above its February 20 closing price of 159.75.

The following compares Zscaler's forward P/S, P/S/G, TTM FCF margin, gross margin, operating margin, and return on invested capital ("ROIC") to its cybersecurity peer group. The market generally considers a company with a higher P/S or P/S/G ratio to be overvalued relative to companies with lower ratios.

Company Name 2027 Forward P/S ratio 2027 Forward estimated revenue growth 2027 Forward P/S ratio-to-estimated revenue growth TTM free cash flow ("FCF") margin TTM Gross Margin TTM Operating Margin TTM ROIC
Zscaler 6.45 19.82% 0.33 32.6% 76.7% -4.7% -13.4%
CrowdStrike (CRWD) 16.70 22.09% 0.76 25.7% 74.1% -8.6% -14.4%
Cloudflare (NET) 17.48 27.29% 0.64 13.3% 74.5% -8.6% -16.3%
Palo Alto Networks (PANW) 8.95 20.09% 0.45 36% 73.5% 14.4% 5.1%
Fortinet (FTNT) 7.08 10.58% 0.67 32.7% 80.5% 30.7% 30.7%
Okta (OKTA) 4.15 9.19% 0.45 31.8% 77.1% -13.9 -6.8%
CheckPoint (CHKP) 5.56 6.04% 0.92 44.3% 86.7% 30.5% 22.4%
SentinelOne (S) 3.67 19.82% 0.19 7.1% 74.7% -33.7% -29.9%

The company's P/S ratio is 6.45, close to the peer median of 6.32, suggesting the stock may be fairly valued. However, its P/S/G is 0.33, well below the peer median of 0.63. Some investors may have concerns relating to the company's long‑term margin expansion, as reflected in its P/S/G trading meaningfully below its peers'. However, bullish investors may interpret the P/S/G trading below its median as a sign of undervaluation.

The company's TTM FCF margin of 32.6% is only slightly above the peer group's median of 32.35%. Be aware that the Rule of 78 calculation uses quarterly FCF margin, while this comparison uses TTM FCF margin, which smooths out the cyclicality of the company's FCF, which fluctuates wildly quarter to quarter. Its TTM gross margin of 76.7% is above the peer group's TTM gross margin of 75.9%. Zscaler's TTM operating margin of -4.7% is below the peer group's median of 6.55%, and its TTM ROIC of -13.4% is below the peer group's median of -0.85%, raising investor concerns about Zscaler's operating efficiency.

Taking all these factors together, the company may be fairly valued, with potential upside if it maintains ARR growth in the low 20s over the next two years, revenue growth of 20% over the next two years, maintains TTM FCF margins in the low 30s or above, and achieves GAAP operating profitability.

Zscaler's TTM non-GAAP price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 49.61 is well above the Information Technology ("IT") median of 22.69, suggesting potential overvaluation or that the market has priced in earnings-per-share ("EPS") acceleration.

The company's FY 2026 forward P/E-to-estimated-EPS growth ("PEG") ratio is 2.26, calculated by dividing its 2026 forward P/E by its estimated EPS growth rate of 16.55%. Typically, growth investors consider high-margin mid-tier SaaS companies like Zscaler to be overvalued when their PEG ratio exceeds 2.0. As a result, at the current PEG ratio, the company may have no upside.

However, the bull case for Zscaler is ARR rising to 25%, Zscaler's AI programs becoming recognized as a winning solution, and its GAAP operating margin turning positive. Investors may then assign it a valuation well above 2.0, and it could have substantial upside.

I don't expect the stock's forward P/E to return to near 100, as it did in July 2025. Still, I think that it could return to 68.73, about halfway back to 100, which is realistic for a high-growth, market-leading cybersecurity stock in the current AI-driven environment. For instance, CrowdStrike's current forward P/E is 72.35, and Cloudflare's is 142.36. Note that although CrowdStrike and Cloudflare have different business models and margin structures, the market frequently values them together as AI‑beneficiary cybersecurity/cloud platforms.

At a forward P/E of 68.37, Zscaler's stock price would be $262.60, a 84% rise over its February 23 closing price of $143.28.

Zscaler has a TTM price-to-FCF (P/FCF) ratio well below its three-, five-, and seven-year medians. Let's throw out its seven-year median, because that likely shows a period where FCF had just transitioned from negative to positive.

The stock's P/FCF trading so much below its three-year median may signal potential undervaluation or concern that FCF profitability is running far ahead of GAAP operating profitability due to the company's high SBC or poor operating efficiency. If Zscaler's FCF margins remain relatively high, while GAAP operating margin expansion stalls, the market may eventually refuse to value it on a P/S or P/FCF and demand to see real GAAP earnings. The market may also punish the stock on even the slightest decline in revenue growth.

Risks

Since running AI workloads may require significant spending on computing power and data, the market is concerned that Zscaler's costs for AI inference compute, memory storage, and large-scale data administration will increase as it ramps up numerous AI products, potentially adversely affecting margins. Robert W. Baird analyst Shrenik Kothari asked the following question on the first-quarter earnings call: "As you're scaling these kind of video-rich products, the AI Guard, and how to think about the margins here?"

"Video-rich products" refers to the fact that Zscaler's products, like ZDX's Digital Experience Monitoring, analyze all data passing through it to stop potential cybersecurity threats. Since Zscaler monitors video traffic through apps like Zoom or Teams, there is concern that processing bandwidth-intensive video streams could cost Zscaler a lot of money, hurting its profit margins.

CEO Chaudry tries to alleviate those concerns with the following answer:

Since the models and things they're using are really on a fairly well confined set of data, we haven't seen any massive change in gross margins. If these things change over time, I'm sure we'll let you guys know.

Note that he never said AI model costs would never become an issue; he just said it wasn't an issue right now. CFO Rubin added:

And maybe just to continue on that thread. Look, for Q1, we're pleased with the margin profile. We're comfortable with the Q2 guide. And then as we look into the back half of the year, you will notice that there's margin expansion in the guide in the back half. We are orientated to growth, but you know that we're also very mindful of the financial model and operating margin.

Investors should closely monitor margins for signs of deterioration from its expansion of AI initiatives. If you begin to see gross margin compression, the AI-powered growth thesis for buying this stock may break down.

Another concern for investors is the macroeconomic environment. Gartner recently published an article that stated: "[A] survey of 367 senior risk and assurance executives – taken in the final quarter of 2025 – revealed that the low-growth economic environment, which relates to financial instability, trade concerns, high unemployment and inflation, continued to concern risk leaders..." A weak economic environment can prompt enterprise customers to slash their IT budgets, potentially hurting Zscaler if organizations delay or cancel spending on its products. CEO Chaudry spoke on the macroenvironment on the company's first-quarter earnings call:

Broadly speaking, there's no significant growth in macro environment. IT budgets remain tight. There is pressure on CIOs [Chief Information Officers]. There is far less pressure on the cyber side of it. So cyber is under less pressure. We do see scrutiny for large deals similar to what we shared in the past. But two areas are still of high interest to customers. One is Zero Trust Security because of all these breaches happening out there and second is AI security because everyone is trying to do some level of deployments of AI applications because CIOs feel like if they aren't doing anything in this area, they'll be viewed as laggards.

So, although the economic environment is a headwind, at this point, it's not enough to bust the investing thesis for Zscaler, because the one area in IT that enterprises are spending money on is cybersecurity, specifically Zero Trust Security and AI security. Investors should monitor earnings calls for management's language on delayed deals causing revenue misses, which would be a symptom of macroeconomic factors affecting Zscaler.

The last significant Zscaler risk that I will cover in this article is Red Canary integration. Although Red Canary is a key piece of Zscaler's "AI-powered SOC (Security Operations Center)" strategy to fight AI threats with AI security agents, analysts are concerned about Red Canary churn. On the first quarter earnings call, Morgan Stanley analyst Meta Marshall asked the following question:

Maybe I just wanted to ask a question about Red Canary and just how it's kind of performing towards expectations given that you guys have been looking at a fair amount of churn within your kind of assumptions for that business. Just any context around that performance would be helpful.

Meta wants to know whether the churn management expected actually materialized. Investors are concerned that Zscaler's guide to "a fair amount of churn" in Red Canary’s ARR base raises legitimate questions about the stability of its customer base, the quality and length of its existing contracts, and whether Zscaler would need to rebuild the book of business from scratch to offset the churn.

Additionally, analysts and investors are concerned that the acquisition will adversely impact margins and ARR, as Red Canary carries several integration risks, including sales-team integration, product-and-engineering-team integration, and the risk that it distracts management from its core Zero Trust business.

CEO Chaudry responded:

The integration of Red Canary with Zscaler is going very well. G&A integration was done right away. The two other main areas were: one, engineering end products. We're integrating Red Canary's agentic AI technology with Zscaler platform doing well. Second is go-to-market. Red Canary's go-to-market team has become security operations specialist team. It's working with our field sales organization, which is uncovering opportunity. So seeing a vast majority of Zscaler Red Canary pipeline is now coming from Zscaler customers.

CFO Rubin added:

Yes. Look, I would just add that Red Canary is trending slightly better than our previous guidance. But keep in mind that we don't believe that Red Canary's contribution is material to our overall business. So as we go forward, we don't intend to provide specific color on Red Canary.

Management answered Meta's question directly and addressed some of the other risks that investors are concerned about. Since Red Canary’s ARR contribution is small relative to Zscaler’s total ARR, its incorporation risk, while real, doesn't break the buy thesis.

Zscaler is still a buy

The company's negative GAAP profitability and lack of meaningful EBITDA make the stock ill-suited for value investors. However, growth‑oriented investors focused on ARR, FCF, and operating leverage may still be interested in Zscaler's potential upside. Since Zscaler has strong FCF margins, growth investors may view it as attractive and not purely speculative despite negative GAAP earnings.

Zscaler's TTM revenue of $2.83 billion is 2.7% of its Serviceable addressable market ("SAM") of $104 billion. So, the company has plenty of room to grow into its end markets.

A bullish scenario of a premium forward P/E of 68.37 implies 84% upside. This stock is suitable for an investor willing to withstand substantial near-term risks. I rate the stock a buy for aggressive growth investors only.

data.title: ClearBridge Value Portfolios Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Markets: U.S. equities finished a strong 2025 with more subdued gains in fourth quarter, with the S&P 500 Index rising 2.7% from October through December to end the year up 17.9%. Information technology stocks led the benchmark 1000 Value Index in the fourth quarter, followed closely by communication services and health care, which saw positive performance thanks to lower policy uncertainty, improved earnings, attractive valuations and a pickup in M&A (mergers and acquisitions) activity. Despite a 25-basis-point cut in the federal funds rate in December, elevated long-term yields weighed on two sectors: real estate and utilities—the latter also suffering as the artificial intelligence trade pulled back.
  • Contributors: Holdings in Micron Technology (MU), Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) and OneMain (OMF). Stock selection in materials, IT and an overweight to health care.
  • Detractors: Holdings in Corcept Therapeutics (CORT), Fiserv (FISV) and Charter Communications (CHTR). Stock selection in the health care, financials and communication services sector and an underweight to the IT sector.
  • Outlook: With value spreads near historic extremes and AI adoption poised to broaden economic benefits, we see an attractive probability gap that creates meaningful upside potential for valuation-driven investors.

Performance Review

  • The Portfolios mildly underperformed their benchmark in a quarter that broadly favored value over growth, as declines in health care overcame strength from technology and materials stocks.
  • Stock selection in the health care sector was the greatest detractor from relative returns in the fourth quarter, largely owing to the decline in drug developer Corcept Therapeutics, whose stock fell following the release of a FDA Response Letter for its relacorilant program, citing the need for additional evidence to support approval. With the prospect of the company having to lean more heavily on its legacy products, which are under pressure from greater generic competition, we elected to exit the position.
  • Our top performer was Micron Technology, which continued to extend its strong 2025 performance following attractive earnings results and upbeat guidance due to accelerating AI-driven demand, tightening memory supply and improving pricing dynamics across DRAM and high-bandwidth memory markets. Performance was also bolstered by copper miner Freeport McMoRan, whose shares advanced alongside the commodity price on improving global growth expectations, a weaker U.S. dollar and continued optimism around long-term demand tied to electrification and energy transition trends.
  • Newmont (NEM), in the materials sector, engages in the production and exploration of gold properties, as well as the exploration for copper, silver, zinc, lead, and other metals. The company's share price moved higher alongside gold prices during the quarter. Additionally, we believe that the market is beginning to recognize discount in the company's share price given the current price of gold and attractive free cash flow generation.
  • Fiserv, in the information technology sector, provides payment and financial services technology. The company's stock declined after reporting disappointing third quarter results, missing earnings expectations, cutting full-year guidance and announcing a leadership shake-up, which raised investor concerns about growth and execution.
  • Charter Communications, in the communication services sector, operates as a broadband connectivity and cable operator company serving residential and commercial customers. The company's stock declined after reporting weak third quarter results with subscriber losses, missing earnings expectations and announcing workforce reductions, which heightened investor concerns about growth and rising costs.
  • In the fourth quarter, we made several changes within our financials holdings. For example, we swapped our exposure within regional banks by replacing M&T Bank (MTB) with Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB). We believe that Fifth Third is poised to accelerate its growth by combining its best-in-class digital strengths with recently acquired AmeriCorps's middle-market franchise in fast-growing, attractive regions in the Southeast, Texas and California, ultimately upgrading our overall return profile.

Outlook

  • At a broad level we underestimated the resilience of the market and the economy to the year's two big volatility events: the reveal of Chinese AI model DeepSeek and President Trump's Liberation Day. Both caused volatility to spike and relative performance pain despite ultimately proving incredibly short lived. The commonality in both is that we underestimated the structural resilience of the U.S. economy and the operating leverage that continues to support best-in-the-world free cash flow (FCF) margins for U.S. companies.
  • On a broad level, the market continues to price value stocks relative to growth at a level that implies value has little chance of leading. Despite a couple of good years, value spreads have remained trapped at the cheapest 10% of their history. We think the catalyst for value's escape will, ironically, come from AI adoption. 2026 will be the year that AI has to justify the immense and accelerating capital investment. To do this, it will need to be diffused more broadly across the economy, driving material productivity gains and higher profit margins. If this occurs, it could narrow the margin, return and earnings growth gap between tech stocks and AI adopters, including value stocks not priced for this structural upside.
  • Ultimately, we believe that the crucible of 2025 has helped sharpen our positioning for 2026. We are actively focused on finding AI adoption in sectors and industries where it is not currently priced, giving us exposure to the upside scenarios as we compound higher growth in a value wrapper. For the downsides, we are focused on companies generating free cash flow and with strong balance sheets. We have also continued to decrease individual stock volatility where we cannot reduce it as part of our portfolio construction. Finally, we are overweight real asset sectors such as energy and materials, which should do well in an inflation scenario while also compounding business value from robust ongoing free cash flow generation.
  • Our main goal is to get back to making active valuation-disciplined investing look simple again, even if it isn't easy. While we approach every new year with humility and a focus on process discipline, we think positioning for many possible futures is critical in a market priced for a narrow set of outcomes — especially when the alternatives have much higher probabilities than what the market has priced. In an increasingly passive world crowded into the same few stocks and sectors, we think that this is a key source of differentiated returns for active, probability-driven managers like us.

Benchmark = Russell 1000 Value Index

The strategy returns shown are preliminary composite returns, subject to future revision (downward or upward).

Past performance is not a guarantee of future results. An investment in this strategy can lose value. Please visit Mutual Funds | ETFs | Insights for the latest performance figures. Investors cannot invest directly in an index, and unmanaged index returns do not reflect any fees, expenses or sales charges.

Fees: Periods less than one year are not annualized. Performance results are for the composite which includes all actual, fully discretionary accounts with substantially similar investment policies and objectives managed to the composite's investment strategy. Composite returns are stated in U.S. dollars and assume reinvestment of any dividends, interest income, capital gains, or other earnings. The composite may include account(s) that are gross of fees and pure gross of fees. "Pure" gross-of-fee returns do not reflect the deduction of any expenses, including transaction costs. A traditional (or "true") gross-of-fee return reflects performance after the reduction of transaction costs but before the reduction of the investment advisory fee. The gross-of-fee return may include a blend of "true" gross-of-fee returns for non-wrap accounts and "pure" gross-of-fee returns for wrap accounts. Net-of-fee returns is reduced by a model "wrap fee" (3.0% is the maximum anticipated wrap fee for equity and balanced portfolios) which includes trading expenses as well as investment management, administrative and custodial fees. The model wrap fee used represents the highest anticipated wrap fee applicable to the strategy. Actual fees and account minimums may vary.

For fee schedules, contact your financial professional, or if you enter into an agreement directly with Franklin Templeton Private Portfolio Group, LLC ("FTPPG"), refer to FTPPG's Form ADV Part 2A disclosure document. Management and performance of individual accounts may vary for reasons that include the existence of different implementation practices and model requirements in different investment programs.

ClearBridge Investments, LLC claims compliance with the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS®). GIPS® is a registered trademark of CFA Institute. CFA Institute does not endorse or promote this organization, nor does it warrant the accuracy or quality of the content contained herein.

To obtain specific information on available products and services or a GIPS Report, contact your Franklin Templeton separately managed account sales team at (800) DIAL BEN/342-5236.

What are the Risks?

All investments involve risks, including possible loss of principal. Small- and mid-cap stocks involve greater risks and volatility than large-cap stocks. International investments are subject to special risks, including currency fluctuations and social, economic and political uncertainties, which could increase volatility. These risks are magnified in emerging markets .

Glossary

Earnings per share is defined as a company's net income divided by the number of outstanding shares of its common stock.

The federal funds rate is the interest rate at which a depository institution lends funds maintained at the Federal Reserve to another depository institution overnight. Also known as the "fed funds rate".

Free cash flow (FCF) is a measure of financial performance calculated as operating cash flow minus capital expenditures.
